title: Surviving GRS recovery alone. Need tips please...
author: RegularUser02x
selftext:
So, I (MtF) am (hopefully) having GRS soon.\
Upon my coming out, all of my relatives either cut contact with me or "don't want to get involved in all of this", including my parents, and all of my "friends" suddenly disappeared after as well, I will be on my own, no support no nothing.

To all who have been through this surgery, what are the tips to prepare well? I guess Airbnb after those 5 or 6 days in hospital and stockpile A LOT of water, food (specifically purrÃ©es), clean clothes... Anything else that's crucial to know for survival? Physical survival or mental one...\
I'm a fucking heroine, so that's not the first time I'm alone but I'm also aware that the GRS recovery (especially hybrid PPT) is extremely difficult...

comments.author: Miss_Emi
comments.body:
I did it alone in Thailand, it went perfectly, but do I recommend it? Fuck no, they had everything set, and I had daily nurse visits, and twice a week examination with suregon. I really had the perfect conditions, and it was STILL difficult, i also had no pain, or major complicatons, apart from granulation.

  
I recommend getting a grabber because bending is a no, no. Honestly, i cant imagine doing this alone, once home, I had EVERYTHING taken cared of. My mom & my sister clean, and cook and do everything for me, and i still find the recovery incredibly difficult. Few weeks away from 3 months, and i STILL cant sit, lift heavy things, wear my skin tight Levi's, or drive my car. Going back to work is out of the question!

  
Reading what you wrote is incredibly worrying, because it seems you are underestimating how serious this surgery is. I applaud anyone doing this on their own, but it is nearly impossible in the long run, and can have major bad consequences, which can set you back for several months, and make revision almost certain.

  
Please think it through, I did over a decade of research before I did this, I went to Suporn Clinic, and they are known for a brutal recovery, but it seems your method might be even more difficult?!?

comments.author: InevitableSong3170
comments.body:
I did medical tourism (traveled to another country where the medical care was fully managed by an office and everything arranged or included). In my opinion, this is the best/only way to do major elective medical care.

I went to another coutry for medical tourism for SRS, but there are a few places in the US where much of the care is fully araged. I don't know where, but I've head about it. Ask around.

They can help with your dressings, showers, getting dressed that first week or two. And itâ€™s good to have someone take out the trash and clean up when youâ€™re resting. comments.author: Ok_Welder3797
comments.body:
Yeahâ€¦.your recovery is going to be seriously set back if you do not have someone with you for at least the first couple weeks. Like Iâ€™m not positive you should even go through with it if you donâ€™t have any caregivers at all.

Itâ€™s crucial to limit your activity as much as possible, and absolutely no stairs bending or lifting, or even really sitting upright. 


Idk that you need purÃ©es? Pretty sure most folks do a normal diet.

If youâ€™re dead set on continuing anyway, just think anything you can do to eliminate steps in your activities of daily living. Pre-prepared things that can be done in a microwave, youâ€™re not going to be able to cook. Get bath wipes to get around standing up to shower for the first bit. Arrange things in your recovery space to be as close together as possible to limit walking as much as possible.

comments.author: onnake
comments.body: Make sure your home after the Airbnb is spic and span and equally well stocked. Make sure they are free of tripping hazards. Be prepared to need to sit or lie down right away  for the first week or two postop until your energy starts coming back. Stock up, too, on things you like to do like movies, books, etc. Be sure you have a 24/7 way of getting help ( contacting your surgical team, trip to the ER) in the probably unlikely event you need it. This surgery may one of the best things youâ€™ll ever do for your mental well-being. Youâ€™ve got it.

comments.author: trueyouapp
comments.body:
You can absolutely get through this, but for GRS (esp. peritoneal) the setup beforehand is *everything*.

**Never skip:**  
**First 2â€“3 days after discharge = 24/7 help** (friend, paid nurse, *anyone*). This is when youâ€™re most vulnerable.  
  
**Pain/swelling peaks around day 3** have ice packs ready and **sleep propped up for 2 weeks** (no lying flat).  
  
**No stairs, heavy lifting, or long upright sitting** for the first couple weeks, this avoids wound separation and setbacks.  
  
**Emergency plan**: direct line to your surgical team + a way to get to the ER fast if bleeding, fever, or sudden swelling hits.

Helpful but not as critical:

\-Stockpile easy-to-open food & water before surgery.

\-Keep essentials at waist height and use a grabber so you donâ€™t bend.

\-Have entertainment ready isolation can hit hard, so plan for podcasts, movies, or online chats.



You got this!! Just donâ€™t push early, and youâ€™ll save setbacks.

comments.author: MaybeAlice1
comments.body:
For me, the first couple weeks were the hardest. Anything that was on the floor was lost to me. I had a few cases of nearly fainting after leaving the hospital that would have been bad without someone at hand. The first week I definitely wanted someone around the clock but, for the most part, they didn't have a lot to do.

By the end of the second week though, I was pretty independent. I could drive and take care of enough of the house stuff that it wasn't a big deal. I was off the opiates and doing just NSAIDs for pain. Support at that point was essentially just emotional and being kept company rather than actually needing things done for me. Maybe some gentle nudging to go do dilations and picking stuff up that I'd dropped.

I also helped my girlfriend through her second week of recovery. It was pretty similar for her. She was up and walking but was pretty low energy and needed some encouragement to do self care. There was some amount of nursing involved there to help trim some errant stitches and such but nothing too involved. I helped with showering and such but that was mostly because we were comfortable with each other.

comments.author: pixiecc12
comments.body: i recovered alone and can not recommend it. its a big operation and mentally it can take a huge toll. post op depression is common (regardless of operation outcome)

comments.author: Soft-Wind9819
comments.body:
I had PPT last year in Bangkok and had a friend staying for my first 2 weeks post discharge but didn't really need help with much physically, they were primarily emotional support/boredom relief.


From my experience I'd say the two most important things for physical survival would be having mobility equipment (e.g. bed transfer rails, walking cane for sitting/standing transfers, waist height trolley to carry things between rooms, bath transfer board if you only have a shower over bath), and having a strong and mobile lower body and core. If you can squat ass to floor with your knees together and get back up without risking falling you can pick up (light) objects from the floor with minimal risk of wound separation etc.


I was back to work for an admin job WFH at 5 weeks and in office for 4 days a week at 8 weeks, so if you have this kind of work it could be doable.


I think my recovery was pretty close to a best case scenario and I did have support available if it wasn't manageable on my own. I'd recommend having at least a contingency plan if you need extra help if at all possible.

comments.author: Mysterious_Code4291
comments.body: Prep meals and put them in the freezer. Iâ€™d say for at least 3-4 weeks.

comments.author: SparkleK_01
comments.body:
I have a girlfriend who did it alone, also in Thailand at a place with excellent follow up care.  Sheâ€™s beautiful and feminine but omg is she tough on the inside.  It took a lot out of her and it could be emotionally and physically exhausting, but she did it.

So it is possible.   But if you choose this path and donâ€™t have someone with you, even part of the time, OP, you need to make sure you are mentally prepared and have a network of friends and support you can chat with via text or FaceTime.  It is an enormous mental effort (even having someone there, like I did).

It sounds like you have a couple years to prepare OP?  In that case I recommend some study and practice in dance (body control and strength), breathing exercises, and meditation.  Those three skills can help immensely.

comments.author: GenevieveSapha
comments.body: Have you considered Vulvaplasty... much less invasive... with easier/shorter recovery.
